The Holocaust in art. El Mole-Rachmim from the series ‘Kamienie krzyczą’ (‘The stones are screaming’), painted in 1946 by Bronisław Wojciech Linke

El Mole-Rachmim’ (‘God full of mercy’) is sung at Jewish funerals and on the Day of Atonement. Except for the period 1939–46, Linke spent most of his working life in Warsaw. He deployed a powerful surrealist form of art to attack cruelty, meanness and hypocrisy

note: to Wilhelmshaven on the North Sea coast of Germany. Independence Regained and Lost, 1914–1945
title: Sherman tanks of the 24th Lancers of General Maczek’s Polish 1st Armoured Division passing through the hamlet of Sommery, north of Rouen, in pursuit of the retreating Germans. The division’s battle route took it from Caen, through Belgium and Holland
General Władysław Anders visiting a resettlement camp for Polish refugees in Kelvedon in Essex

Imprisoned by the Soviets in 1939–41, Anders then commanded the Polish army in the USSR before leading the Polish Second Corps in the Middle East and Italy. The charismatic Anders became a living embodiment of Polish military valour during the Second World War and of the émigré cause after
For the communist regime in Warsaw he was a hated symbol of reaction. He died in 1970 and is buried among his soldiers who fell at Monte Cassino
